Description: Fragment of a block carved from black basalt. Block from the soubassement of the temple of Amun-Ra, inscribed and decorated in sunk relief. Under a continuous strip of sky with stars, representation of a quadripatite geographical procession. Personifications of districts of Lower Egypt (groups of four representing each nome) walking towards left, alternating male 'Nile' gods (1 preserved) and goddesses (2 preserved). Each bears on their head the sign of a nome of Lower Egypt as well as offerings on their outstretched hands. To each deity belongs a hieroglyphic inscription of six columns. On this block one goddess represents the 'w' region (cultivated land) and the male figure the 'pehu' region (swampy area) of nome 5, and a further goddess represents nome 6. Above and in between the nomes’ personifications is a hieroglyphic inscription incised in fifteen vertical columns.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Egyptian Ministry of Antiquities. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

This block belongs to the lower course of the temple of Amun-Ra in Naukratis, built by Ptolemy I Soter I, whose cartouches appear in the inscription (see facsimile by Edgard 1922, 4). It was discovered in 1914 with two other blocks in ‘different parts of the site’ of Naukratis (Edgar 1922, 2). They were once kept in the Museum of Tanta (Tanta Museum inv. Nr. 1016; 983+988+991+994+1002; third block unnumbered), before being transferred in a deposit at Tell Basta in 1995. A further fragment, decorated with ‘androgynous Nile-figures’ bringing offerings, seen in the village of El-Noqrash, probably joins this block (mentioned by Griffith in Gardner 1888, 80; Griffith 1890, 69).The composition and the inscription clearly relate these blocks to two blocks today in the Kestner Museum 19070.38-39. The decoration of the temple of Amun is under study by D. von Recklinghausen. On the decorated soubassement of Ptolemy I in Naukratis: Bernand, A. 1970, Le Delta égyptien d’après les textes grecs. I.
